Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Machinery of Mechano-sensitivity in Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports fundamental research to identify and test molecules essential for cells to respond and adapt to external physical perturbations. The epithelial tissue is a physical barrier that separates the internal structures of the human body from the outside. The epithelial tissues consist of individual cells that are highly inter-connected by cell junctions. These junctions are dynamic, and respond to mechanical perturbations, yet, little is known about how cells sense physical forces at a molecular level. The new strategy generates a spatial map of proteins under different physical perturbations, and identifies unique protein-to-protein interactions that may be responsible for force-sensing. Identification of force-sensitive molecular arrangement is essential for fundamental understanding of tissue mechanics. This interdisciplinary research also supports outreach efforts to promote science careers especially in under-represented groups.

Physical force emerged as a key regulator of tissue homeostasis, and plays an important role in embryogenesis, tissue regeneration, and disease progression. Currently, the details of protein interactions under elevated physical stress are largely missing, therefore, preventing fundamental, molecular understanding of mechano-transduction. This research is based on an innovative biochemical strategy to identify force-induced protein interactions surrounding zyxin, a unique force-sensing protein. Using promiscuous biotin ligase to label proximal proteins and cell stretch device to exaggerate forces exerted to cell junctions, the research team will determine how the composition of proteins surrounding zyxin changes with the application of substrate stretch, then test the roles of these proteins during the force-generating events. Furthermore, the precise force-dependent protein-protein interactions will be analyzed using mutational approaches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to tease out how cells sense physical forces from surrounding environment and neighboring cells. Many cells constantly experience physical stimulation and respond by changing their behavior. Yet, we know very little about the protein machinery involved in force-sensing signaling pathway. We designed a cell stretcher compatible with our analysis to apply physical stimulation to live cells. During cell stretching, small molecule tracers (biotin) specifically labels new protein interactions inside the cells. Which proteins are labeled by biotin is controlled by the proximity to the enzyme responsible for catalyzing this reaction. This means that the placement of this enzyme inside the cell is crucial. We tagged this enzyme with zyxin, a protein known to be force-responsive, and probed how protein interactions change surrounding zyxin. We were able to detect known, suspected, and new force-dependent protein interactions, and validate these interactions using complimentary experiments. This proof-of-concept experiment enabled comprehensive analysis of force-dependent protein interactions surrounding zyxin. This type of protein interactions are essential for normal and abnormal (e.g., in disease state) functions of cells and tissues and previously inaccessible with traditional techniques. The application of this approach will be critical for all processes involving processes that depend on physical stimulation. This project supported 10 undergraduate students and 2 high school students, and they conducted experiments, analyzed the resulting data and disseminating the findings in research conferences and as publications. Furthermore, the project supported annual outreach program from 2017-19, organized by the graduate students in our department. This outreach event, Biomedical Design Challenge, invited local community college students to take part in engineering design process and expose to research programs at UC Davis.
